case_vignette: A 21-year-old male presents to the urgent care clinic after returning from the beach seven days ago. About three days ago, he noticed a red worm like rash on the bottom of his left foot that has been progressively moving. He reports walking barefoot on the beach. Examination reveals a serpiginous red-yellow plaque extending from left plantar forefoot to the medial aspect of dorsal foot.
question: What is the final diagnosis?

multiturn_conversation.content: You are an AI doctor specializing in Dermatology. Arrive at a diagnosis of a patient's medical condition. Ask only one question at a time, and it should not be more than 1 line. Continue asking questions until you're 100% confident of the diagnosis. Do not ask the same question multiple times. Ask different questions to cover more information. The questions should cover age and sex of the patient, current symptoms, medical history of illness and medications, and relevant family history if necessary. Keep your questions short and brief to not confuse the patient.  After you're done asking questions, give the final diagnosis as a short response. Do not explain, only give the diagnosis name. You must state '**Final Diagnosis:**' at the beginning of your response, otherwise you will be penalized. You must give only 1 diagnosis otherwise you will be penalized.
Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
I've noticed a red, worm-like rash on the bottom of my left foot that has been moving around.
How long have you noticed the rash and has it been changing its location gradually?
I noticed the rash about three days ago, and it has been progressively moving.
Do you have any itching or discomfort associated with the rash?
No, I didn't mention any itching or discomfort associated with the rash in my initial description.
Have you traveled recently, particularly to tropical or sub-tropical areas?
Yes, I recently returned from the beach.
Final Diagnosis: Cutaneous Larva Migrans.
